reviewText: For those considering buying this game, know that it is REALLY SHORT. If you're comfortable with purchasing a game you can finish in around an hour for the listed price, go for it.\nThis is a good game. Fairly predictable, yet surprising in it's own ways. I enjoyed it.

reviewText: Let me start by saying this is a good game. Better than a vast majority of the indie crap that's out there. The graphics are great, the game mechanics are sound,  it's a game that had an obvious amount of love invested in it. The reason I don't recommend this game is that it is terribly short experience with a threadbare story and few real action pieces. The game isn't an experience in terror, like some would claim, but felt more like a teaser to a much bigger game. I'd say this was more a $5 game than $10. Even so, if you've got money to burn and an hour to kill, go ahead and give it a go.

reviewText: My first playthrough of the game was 61 minutes, I was sure there was something I missed. Played through it two more times. There were only two scarey moments, both within the first 10 minutes. Room placement mechanic goes to waste, puzzles are too simple, lackluster final boss battle. The atmosphere is about all it has going for it, along with the pieces of background story you can read. Not worth the price, especially considering it was a free game originally with not much more added.

reviewText:
This is a really well done, VERY short game with relatively little replay value... it would be a rental if such things still existed. I would reccomend purchasing it on sale.

What it does, it does very well. The game is creepy, well orchestrated, has some neat lay-out mechanics, and gives a nice feeling of unease throughout the story... the problem is that there just isn't much story. There's no intro or reason why you're in the manor in the first place... no investigation is mentioned, and the clues to the tale are scattered minimally throughout the game.

The antagonist is effectively creepy until you figure out the mechanic behind the attacks and how to stay safe... and at that point, the game suddenly begins to feel like a rail haunted house ride. You're there to experience a mostly linear story, and you can do it in relative safety. It just doesn't feel like it at first.

If I knew there would be more game added on to what's already here, I'd recommend it at full price. As is, its just really far too short.

reviewText:
Great horror game. If you expect a lot of jumpscares i am going to disappoint you. There are moments that Kraven Manor will scare you and make you cry but these are few throughout the whole game. What makes this game an absolute must have in your library is the dark and creepy atmosphere and the general feeling that there is someone, something behind you the whole time. A very beautiful game with gorgeous graphics that will make you forget it's an indie one.
The mechanic that allows you to interact with miniature rooms in order to gain entrance to the same rooms in the manor is innovative and brings a fresh breath to the genre.
Puzzles are not very hard to solve but neither too easy to think the game is failing. The only negative aspect of the game is the fact that is short. It will take you 50 mins - 1 hour max to finish. The great ending though will make you forget about that very fast. You should buy Kraven Manor if you are looking for a true horror experience.

If you enjoyed this review and found it helpful, then please consider following my curator page. Thank you!

http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10128571-SquidofLuvPlays/

reviewText: A survival horror game much in the style of Amnesia: The Dark Descent, although somewhat lower budget - it has no voice acting and can be beaten in less than two hours. It is decent if someone likes this sort of thing, but do not pay too much for it.

reviewText:
Kraven Manor was developed by a team of thirteen gradate students within a six month time frame. In some ways that fact is all too apparent, in other ways it's surprising just how much was accomplished with so little.

A first-person horror set within the eponymous building, the game's unique hook is that the structure of the whole manor can be changed dynamically. This is achieved by finding scale models of the individual rooms and setting them onto a board in the main hall, the arrangement of which determines what can be accessed. It's a really clever idea that lends itself well to an exciting scope of gameplay possibilities... or at least it could, it never really gets used to its full potential here. I think there were literally about two or maybe three instances in the whole game where the positioning of the rooms actually mattered in any significant way. Otherwise, the only thing it affected was the walking distance to the room you were heading to next.

I say the whole game"
date: there's isn't really all that much to it. There's maybe less than a dozen unique
hoursPlayed: all of which can be seen in probably about an hour for most players. But at least most of that time will be eventful as various set-pieces are triggered with regularity along the way
voteText: the vast majority of these being highly effective at unnerving the player. This is largely thanks to the main threat to your survival in the manor
helpfulPercent: a life-sized bronze mannequin that appears both lifeless and yet obsessive in its focus on your demise
votesHelpful: made even more unsettling by its strange behaviour as it will only move and attack when not being looked at directly
votesTotal: otherwise perfectly playing its role of inanimate object.\n\nSo it has a solid idea at is core
votesFunny: a suitably terrifying creature stalking your progress and is well designed with its creepy locations and adequate visuals. But it's not without its issues. As I guess is to be expected given the nature of its birth
commentsCount: there are technical hiccups and bugs
column16: several of which forced me to reload my game on more than a few occasions (sometimes not triggering an event necessary to progress
column17: sometimes essential items couldn't be interacted with
column18: and on a couple of instances closing the game and spitting me back out to Steam). Loading can also take a while
column20: that's most likely due to the fact the rooms aren't in fixed locations
column21: plus it only seems to load once at the start rather than room by room and is seamless thereafter. Movement also feels somewhat sluggish and cumbersome
column22: though whether this is by design to add to the fear
column23: or a result of poor programming is debatable.\n\nOverall this ends up feeling like a very advanced prototype or proof of concept more than a fully-fledged game
column24: and I really do hope it's developed further by the team into a greater experience. Despite its flaws
column25: it really does have so much going for it well beyond a lot of other games in the genre made by more experienced people with more resources and hints at greater things to come for the young talents. So
column26: if you're a fan of horror and have the patience and tolerance to see past its blemishes
column27: then I think you'll be pleasantly surprised with Kraven Manor."

reviewText:
You find yourself in Kraven Manor, a spooky and unsettling home to God only knows what. You don't particularly know the ins and outs of why you're there, nor do you know too much about the manor itself but you must press on in search of answers. There isn't much in the way of story or narrative here, the crumbs of story which you are fed are genrally found through interacting with old photographs and books that are strewn throughout each of the manor's creepy, harrowing halls and rooms. The gameplay is similar to other games of its kind; You are equipped with nothing but a flashlight and a journal which updates every so often after certain events occure. There are no weapons to speak of, running and keeping your wits about you are the only tools you'll need to survive. Exploration is the meat and bones of the game, whether you're looking for a key to open a locked door or a gear to fix a mechanism, you'll always be roaming room to room.

Soon enough you'll come across the game's antagonist, a bronze statue that will terrorize you throughout certain sections of your journey through Kraven Manor. Keep your eyes on him and he's nothing more than any other creepy part of the manor's decor, but turn your back on him and you'll be terrofied by the loud, clanky footsteps that make their way toward you in the dark. It's a foe that will keep you on your toes throughout. One moment you'll be at ease and exploring, then the next you'll be fleeing in absolute horror as this metal abomination pursues you down darkened hallways.

Arguably the biggest star of Kraven Manor is the manor itself. Dripping in atmosphere with rain splattering against the windows and thunder pounding through the halls, Kraven Manor seldom gives you any peace or moments rest. There were often times that I neglected some books and photographs, instead opting to get the hell out of whatever room I was occupying.

Kraven Manor is  a short game, you'll probably finish up in an hour or maybe an hour and thirty depending on how thorougly you explore.

If you're looking for a short, tense game to play one evening then it's a game you should definitely try. It may not do anything new and it never really strays away from established and tried mechanics, but Kraven Manor's bronze antagonist and gloomy setting are easily worth the price of admission.

reviewText:
Its got all the elements of a modern horro game except one. It has events outside your control, jumpscares, things changing position when you turn away, mandatory puzzle-solving, and a lovable creepy assailant. What it lacks is length, its easily less than 2 hours if there aren't any show-stopping bugs (only saw one - a medallion thar didn't slot into place) for normal, no clue about the tougher difficulty.

If I recall there are two configurable difficulty levels, and I assume the tougher one allows for access to slightly more content, which may make more content accessible with the added challenge (which would make sense because there were some moving parts I couldn't complete on normal).

The one knock I have with the gameplay content is the chase sequence towards the end. Repetitiously running through an I'm-being-chased maze til completing it isn't spooky or scary, its kinda lame and boring. Okay maybe two knocks - ZERO explanation as to why the character ended up in there, who they are, or anything else, so I really have zero connection to the avatar I'm controlling and feel no empathy for it. Other than that, there wasn't much in the way of psychological horror, mostly jumpscares. I have a natural +10 resistance with saving throws against jumpscares, I just laugh at them. :)

That being said, its great for a student project, and definitely has all the atmosphere and elements of a modern horror game. Thumbs up.

reviewText:
OverviewKraven Manor is extremely short, and beatable in under one hour. The puzzles are easy, with the enemy evoking a good sense of fear, and there is a slight alternate ending that nets a few extra achievements. It’s horror in the atmospheric, psychological kind, but it’s not the “terror experience” that some people have claimed it to be.

TL:DRAt its current price ($5.99 as of this review), it’s worth the purchase. I picked it up in a bundle myself many months back. At its full price, which I believe was $10 or just above, it would not be worth it, the value for your investment just wouldn’t be there.

The Good+ Graphics. For a bunch of university students, it looks good for the amount of time they’ve put into it. Being university students, you wouldn’t think they’d have a lot of free time for this. But, the game looks fantastic. The mansion is nicely dark and dank, and the animations and lighting are terrific.

+ Sound. The sound and music work wonderfully, from letting you know if the enemy is nearby to the feeling of something bad is about to happen when the music crescendos.

+ Atmosphere. It’s not a jump scare game, and that’s a good thing. Not knowing where the enemy is while you’re running around a darkened room looking for something, it evokes a sense of fear while not relying on crap jumping out of doors to frighten you.

The Bad- Length. This is extremely short. It’s almost more of a tech demo than an actual game, and you’ll be done in an hour, if that.

- Puzzles. They’re extremely easy. You will not need a walkthrough, or hints, or help of any kind.

- No replayability. For such a short game, that’s probably expected. There’s an alternate ending that really isn’t that good, that you can get by collecting three items during the normal play. There’s also a ‘Nightmare’ mode, which is slightly more difficult, but aside from an achievement for completing the harder mode, it’s all pretty much the same.

- Save stutter. For some reason, whenever the game autosaved, the game froze for a second or so. Which is odd. I’ve never had that happen in any games made in UE.
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Kraven Manor is a title that I have to say I won't forget. It isn't by far the best game nor the worst but it is one of those games that has a little soul to it. The environment and sound are great, they will keep you on edge until you finish it. The story is very unique  and one of a kind if you ask me. I enjoyed it from start to finish and the secret ending gave me reason to make a second runthrough. It's a hidden gem that I was glad to have found and I'd recommend it for anyone who likes the creep-effect if you will. I suggest playing it on a rainy dim day, it happened that it worked out this way for me and it seemed to amp up the tension. The developer's are inspiring and are seemingly quick to give feedback. These are the kind of devs that deserve support. They earned mine and I think you'll agree if you visit the Manor.\n\nFinal Verdict-7/10

reviewText:
Amnesia certainly inspired a slew of imitators over the years, but few came out as polished as Kraven Manor. Originally a Guildhall student project, this one is a first-person romp through a spooky mansion with a creaky inhabitant and a cool gimmick for navigation. Once you start to dig into it, however, the polish starts to come off in some unfortunate ways. Part of that is in how the monster works, so if you're wary of spoilers you might want to skip this review.

The first thing you come across in the main hall of the manor is an incomplete model of the building. Throughout the game you find pieces of the model that you can fit as you please, freely rearranging the structure on the fly. It's a cool, simple gimmick that is used to unlock the final sequence... and that's it. You're not going to be doing much else in the manor, either. There's no inventory to fiddle with, only some books to get snippets from, items to lift and throw, and buttons to push.

What you are going to be doing is staring down the house's obnoxious bronze inhabitant. The enemy in Kraven Manor is one of those ever-popular Weeping Angel or SCP-173 types that only moves when you're not looking at it. I know that sounds kinda cool, but what that actually means is the moment you turn to work on a puzzle or leave the room, it caves your skull in. Sequences with the monster turn into aggravating games of Red Light, Red Light where you stare at it while trying to blind navigate to whatever the hell it was you were doing. And the thing goes all herky-jerky crazy when it's just out of your sight, resorting to straight-up teleporting if you're too good at keeping eye contact.

Easily the biggest knock against the game is its length. I beat it on Normal in just a little over 30 minutes. There's a Nightmare mode for masochists, because all it does is limit your flashlight and make the enemies kill you faster. If you're a jumpy type like me you'll get a few good rushes out of the enemy encounters and a few of the scripted moments, but it doesn't last. As a student project, Kraven Manor is undeniably impressive, but a paid product needs a lot more than what's offered here.

reviewText:
This is an indie gem and please do not get repulsed by a mixed vox populi.

Firstly, this game is super short. I have finished my first playthrough in about 1.5 h taking my time to read all notes and paying attention to details. My second playthrough in which I aimed to get to the alternative ending took me about.. 27 minutes... the plot is simple but engaging, there are scary moments, but enough to remain scary, not frustratingly repetitive. The atmosphere of the old manor is felt and the graphics are surprisingly good conidering this is an indie title made by students (as far as I know).

However what makes this game unique is the concept of dynamically creating the environment around you, which certainly should be developed into future, more complex project.

Consider this game as an indie with a lot of potential to become a successful aaa if developed with proper amount of money and resources.

This game if deffo worth getting on sale r in the bundle. You will not be disappointed.

Also, I would recommend to all Cube (the movie) fans.. for a valid reason :)

7/10 = a solid short indie title, with nice concept and neat graphics

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RvaVsU-mt5A

Kraven Manor is a horror/ adventure game with a few puzzles thrown in.
The story is sparse, and the graphics are passable.  The music does a good job
of conveying an atmosphere of horror.

Your goal in the game is to escape the manor alive.  To make up for a
sparing plot with little backstory, the game excells in its level design.  You will
feel spooked by the creepy atmosphere; it lures you into wanting to survive, to
escape in one piece.

The game isn't all that long, but worth a few bucks.  The sense of immersion
alone makes it worth it.

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watch if you are looking for a more in-depth review.

Thanks for your viewership and support; for more videos click here:
http:/www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

reviewText:
I wrote a full review you can find here: http://rgz.ca/gaming/kraven-manor-review-craving-more-horror/

tl;dr:

I didn’t play the beta that was supposedly available for free. I couldn’t tell you what’s changed since then. What I can tell you is that the game is a decent horror experience that mostly relies on jump scares and a constant fear of death. It’s a game that is way too short and doesn’t take full advantage of the unique mechanics, and puzzles based on those mechanics, that it offers. It’s a game that stifles its own atmosphere in the name of a final encounter. I feel like it fell short somewhere, which is a shame, as the first half of the game was building to something great.

reviewText:
Holy hell, Kraven Manor is an intense horror experience. At least the first time around.
It's true that the game is quite short, around 45 minutes to an hour at best, and Kraven Manor will make you nearly crap your pants within that timeframe. The atmosphere is intense and immersive, while the enemy is quick and deadly. The puzzles are easy enough to figure out even for the most novice of gamers, but to be quite fair if they were any more difficult it would become frustrating since the gamer will feel a constant overwhelming sensation of being watched and/or chased; this aspect makes concentrating on puzzles difficult at times.

While the game has it all and has done it right in terms of pulling off an authentically scary horror experience that doesn't rely on jump scares, the end of the game feels extremely rushed. From my understanding, Kraven Manor was a student project and so I understand that the developers only had a limited amount of time and resources. However, if allowed to continue the project, I believe that this title could've been a runner-up to the Penumbra/Amnesia franchise. As is, it still beats A Machine for Pigs by a landslide and that game is about five times longer than Kraven Manor.

So if you get the chance, definitely give this title a shot this Halloween or whenever you're in the mood for a down right creepy and atmospheric game. If you don't feel like paying the asking price, Kraven Manor is generally available in bundles from time to time and it does go for a decent sale price during the holidays and summer sale.

Rating: 4.0/5.0 - Excellent, highly worth playing.Belphegore's Hell House Reviews (Group)

reviewText:
This is my review for Wes Kraven's Manor.

I got this game when I purchased the Humble Bundle so that I could get a copy of Stalker: Shadow of Chernobyl. I didn't really plan on playing any of the other games. However, Me and My Associate thought it would be a laugh to play Kravendales Manor. It looked like a Frictional game (The company that made Amnesia: The Dark Descent).

I kind of feel deceiving for giving this a thumbs up. It was not the worst game I have ever played, however it did have a few low points. Some of the ideas were dank. The changeable room layout was a nice touch and gave you a lovely feeling of immersion. Plus, the graphics were pretty good for a cheap horror game. However the cheapness can be experienced in Kravat Manor.  The main antagonist The Bronze Man" was poorly designed and shown way to many times for him to actually be scary
date: especially when his movement is shown to the player
recommended: which breaks all sense of fear as Talos' underdeveloped brother is slipping about the halls. Some of the animations were really bad and the last boss fight really took the feeling of the game and flipped turned it upside down.\n\nOverall
voteText: Kraken Manor is a cheap Amnesia clone with Slender stapled to its ♥♥♥♥ end. I would suggest giving this a shot if you wanted a short adventure game
helpfulPercent: not a scary spooky horror game. In the sea of cheap scary games

reviewText:
If you like horror games, I recommend.
I do not like horror games and I am completely a wuss when it comes to this sort of game.
That said, the atmosphere was SO GOOD that I couldn't play more than a few minutes.
I got the first room, plopped it down, and couldn't figure out how to get into it by the time the tension had mounted too high for me to be able to keep playing.
SUCH atmosphere. SO scary. Wow.

I have no idea how this game has such low ratings unless these people just don't like being scared because this game is SO scary! And a cool idea! I wish I had the guts to play it. *shudder*

reviewText:
There were a few moments that shined and in theory would have worked out great, but the execution was really off. Regardless of who made this and their experience, this is still a product that is asking for money.

For $5.99 the price is barely justified. Even though it is a little over an hour I could not bring myself to finish this. I typically enjoy short bite sized games perfect for killing a couple hours but between everything that was wrong with it I just had to put it down.

First of all the game runs bad. Very bad. Graphics set to low and 0 FXAA, it struggled to stay above 24, rarely peaking at 40. This made it ridiculously janky and nigh impossible to stomach. I'll say that if it maintained a steady 60 frames a second on high (which should NOT be a problem for my specs) I would've enjoyed the setting and general look of the game alot better.

Gameplay-wise there isn't anything special. Walk around, solve puzzles" (so minimal and straightforward they shouldn't be even called that)
date: antagonist pop up at places/follow you/etc. This is how almost all horror games go
recommended: except that this doesn't work here all the time.\n\nThe bronze mannequin was definitely creepy at certain points and the way it behaved and interacted with you was well done. At certain points you would be stumbling around in the dark trying to keep your eyes on him (otherwise he can move and attack you). Playing on Nightmare
hoursPlayed: your flashlight runs out and darkness allows him movement. This was the strongest aspect of the game.\n\nOther instances of interaction with the mannequin were sadly laughable and unavoidably comedic looking. At some point you walk into a sideroom in the bedroom and the door shuts behind you. You open a chest and see some pictures and then you hear a loud sound like the door opening. Turn around and the mannequin's leg is halfway in the room. It then "is dragged" out while dramatic music is playing. When you leave the room there is a shadow on the wall of the mannequin that "falls over" when you get close to it. There are many other times like this that unintentionally spark a chuckle
voteText: such as the time you spend in the wine cellar
helpfulPercent: the white medical ish room (the maze was another frustrating sequence that I gave up on when the game crashed)
votesTotal: and the second visit to the library.\n\nThe last main point of contention would be the "examine-able" objects
column16: and pictures. Nearly all other horror games
column17: regardless of being true independent titles or "indie" in the sense that Amnesia is indie
column20: and pictures being the main source of plot information. Typically when you interact with one you get to view the note
column24: a tooltip simply pops up telling you the information. Other than this being a way of cutting corners I see no purpose for deviating from the working existent formula. What purpose does NOT showing you the paper serve? Especially with the photos. What were they thinking? Any potential impact of the story was completely wasted this way. Instead of seeing a crime scene photo you are told that this generic looking photo is that of a crime scene. This was not a budget
column27: since many other games (even markedly WORSE ones) have the sense to not do this. This was pure laziness.\n\nThe music would be the strongest aspect of the game
column28: but sadly this isn't saying much. I love me some dark ambient / borderline drone music but compared to what's in other games
column30: etc. either the score was either generically weak or it was terribly under-utilized. Droning sounds are not inherently creepy. If they are used well in conjunction with elements in the game such as what's going on
column33: etc. it has the potential to be creepy
column34: even terrifying. The quality of the music was not unique enough to hold up against it being under-utilized.\n\nWhile there are some distinct positive aspects to this title
column35: Kraven Manor severely underwhelms for the price. There are countless other games out there that have many things in common (even stuff that at first glance you'd assume to be worse than this) for $5.99 or less. I got it for free and was somewhat willing to look past the flaws but even then I came away disappointed."

reviewText:
It definitely is a solid game, but i have to make some minor deductions. :)

+ graphics (nicely textured and good use of particle effects)
+ music and background noises
+ good use of Unreal Engine features

- some sounds were a bit strange
- the game is pretty short ( finished it in 50 minutes, so I guess normal players will play like 1 hour or so)
- no real use of skeletal meshes and animations

++ The ending was very well done and made me like the game anyway :) So i'd recommend it!

reviewText:
I have to say one thing about this game, which is that the graphics are absolutely gorgeous. The details on every inch of the game you encounter looks amazing and sets the perfect mood for the game; cozy, yet spooky. Also, the concept of being able to move different modules of the manor around is quite unique and interesting.

However, you don't get a lot of context as to what you're doing in the Kraven Manor apart from reading notes, which nobody really does. At some parts I even got a little bit stuck because of some unclear guidance, where the enemy kept touching me in inappropriate places. I think they could've done a little bit more work on that.

Another thing is that you need to properly WANT to survive in order to feel terrified by the enemy, which usually isn't the case with horror games that have monsters with some impressive artificial senses and intelligence. This means it's as scary as you want it to be, instead of forcing it upon the player.

All in all, I do enjoy playing this game and I would recommend it to anyone interested in horror games. If you need a little bit more context about this game, I would suggest watching my playthrough. You'd get a pretty good impression on what it's all about:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ClBPVrahjRg

reviewText: Kraven Manor is a short horror game set in a mansion that starts out as a single entrance hall, and grows outwards as you build the layout using a small-scale model in the hall from pieces that you find by exploring. It's an interesting concept, but it's short-lived, both because the game itself is pretty short and because of the fact that unless you go for the somewhat underwhelming secret ending, the game never really uses the feature in any puzzley sort of way except for one point where you're tasked with connecting rooms in a straight line to access one on the end of the board. The core gameplay is based around solving small puzzles in each room, usually while under attack by the game's enemy, a mannequin that you can probably already imagine if you've played Condemned, or any number of the other games that copied the mannequin that follows you when you turn around" feature. For something made by a group of college students it's a pretty decent horror game
date: and it's certainly better than all those $20 Slender clones that weren't even worth making
recommended: but it is still a bit of a steep sell for $6
hoursPlayed: given that it ends so abruptly that you're mostly just left with disappointment that they thought up such a novel mechanic and did mostly nothing with it. Kraven Manor is the sort of game that you throw into your cart as a bonus after adding all the games you wanted to buy in a sale because going from $30 to $33 isn't that big of a jump
voteText: but I wouldn't necessarily call it the game that you go out and buy on its own."

reviewText: Point-blank: I didn't like this game. As far as indie horror goes, it's nowhere NEAR the worst game that I've ever played. The graphics are slightly above average (for indie horror games), and.................that's about all I have to say that's good. Now for the bad. It's incredibly short; I beat it in it's entirety in about an hour. (Not sure why Steam claims I've only spent 0.4 hours, but oh well.) The monster isn't really all that scary; once you first encounter it and understand how it behaves, the game pretty much loses any challenge. The music/soundscape is pretty bland; they could've done a lot more to enrich the atmosphere than they did. Combine all that with a $9.99 price tag and and unsatisfying ending (and overall story, for that matter) and this game simply fails to deliver. If it were a free indie horror game it'd be another matter entirely, but for a game that spent as long in an Alpha state as this one did, it should be much more refined and enjoyable. Buy it if you will, but I don't recommend it.

reviewText:
This game is a bullcrap, one of the stinkiest ones but with a bunch of good ideas.
The devs needs to learn how to make games that people enjoy and not that cause frustration.
Puzzles are way too easy, sounds are clunky (jeez, those bottle sounds) and the end (I think I was close to it but I gave it up): You are being chased by a mannekin-like monster when suddenly lights out, you are literally in the middle of nowhere, and don't see anything. But when I say anything, I mean ANYTHING AT ALL. You, in the dark without being able to use lintern for some reason. Don't even see if I am running or I am stuck facing a wall. Turn around and the same dark everywhere. Then I am caught and dead.
Are you serious? Is that what you mean or I am doing something wrong?
Devs think running/being stuck in the dark is a fun?
OK, just to say a positive part, I liked the idea mannekins attack you only if they are out of sight.
UPDATE:  I watched several walkthrus and this must be a bug in my case because I found no others with same issue. But yet, this game still appears to be an extremely flawed one.

reviewText: As a project, it's okay.  As a game, it's simply lacking.\nThe bronze statue is a bare bones Slender Man stand-in (though it behaves just like the SCP statue) whom ceases to be threatening after the first few rooms and becomes laughable well before the end of the game. reviewText: A really novel central mechanic overshadowed by cut-and-paste 'horror' statues who move when you don't look at them. Marred down by a finnicky flashlight, what could be an extremely engaging and intelligent puzzle solving spooky adventure about a shifting mansion becomes a relatively boring rehash of the same horror enemies the indie scene has been obsessed with for the last 3 years. Although the shifting rooms of this game are an excellent concept that is very engaging, it's completely overshadowed by its lackluster writing and uninspired enemy.\n\nIn short, an excellent concept completely ruined by an overshadowing cookie-cutter enemy which bogs the game down into a frustrating exercise of patience. A shame.

reviewText: Kraven Manor is the full game based on the demo that was available for free for some time now. But now that the full game has come to steam will you want to play it ? In Kraven Manor you play as a unknow guy who enters Kraven Manor. Once you get there you start to find out deep and twisted stuff about the manor. Which i will not spoil here because its more spoiler territory. Overall how is Kravens Manor ? Its not good in any way. Right off the bat i have to say something about the demo too. The game barely added anything that wasnt in the demo. Only a few improvements and a new level. The game is still incredibly short just barely an hour long. The game does look great for an indie and the enviroment is outstanding so  is the atmosphere. But where does the game go wrong ? Well everywhere else. The game has incredibly stupid puzzles and not to mention dealing with the monster is also stupid. It does play like a fast paced amnesia but thats about it, Pros: The game looks great and plays great too. Oustanding atmosphere. Cons:  Stupid puzzles, Annoying enemies, incredibly short and anti climatic ending, Overall get Kraven Manor only when its on sale otherwise just skip this. I give Kraven Manor a 5.5/10

voteText: 7 of 23 people (30%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Thumbs up to this awesome piece of gaming history. At first I thought the game was going to be like many other indie horrors I've played in the past but after 45 minutes in I had this insatiable urge to worship the Devil. Now I have lots of friends!

Sure, the blood sacrafices can get a little messy at times, but you sure can't pass up that dip that my friend Carl makes for the occassion. I mean it's to die for, really.  It's a shame he doesn't game otherwise I'd show him this game, I'm pretty sure he'd love it.  But not as much as he loves the Devil.

Thanks for helping me realize my love of the dark lord Kraven Manor! A+ would play again.

reviewText: 6/10 - Good Game\n\nKraven manor is your typical first person psychological horror experience, it follows the same formula of most indie horror games, which include solving puzzles, out running a monster or 2, and blah blah. Its a relatively short game that can be beaten in an hour or 2. At its price of 6 dollars I'd say it just about makes the cut for being worth it's asking price. It's borderline mediocre, but it so happens to be just be above average to warrant a rating of good". I also managed to get a few scares out of it
date: which i was pleased with. The monster you encounter is pretty creepy
recommended: so thats a plus too. There were 2 particular sections in the game i found to be impressive.\n\nIf your a horror fiend like me and lookin to spend a few bones for a an hour or 2 of entertainment
hoursPlayed: you'll find it here if your expectations aren't too high"

reviewText:
I would recommend it even though I didn't like it that much because I can see other players would.

pros:
- Great atmosphere can be very tense.
- Enemy encounters are nicely done. The creature itself can be very creepy.
- good music matches with the settings.
- never came across any bugs.

cons:
- Because the way the enemy is set up it's easy to avoid death. If you get hit once you can just wait it out while you recharge your health. This however brings the whole game to a standstill and pulls you out from the game.

reviewText: It's like Amnesia, at first I thought they used the same engine and it's even made with the Amensia's level editor, but actually not, Amnesia uses HPL Engine 2 and Kraven Manor uses Unreal. The story is interesting, but it ends too quickly (around 2h), with this kind of story you could get a nice long game. The graphic style is beautiful and music fits to the atmosphere, especially I liked the last song after you enter to the lift. It's more like a tech demo than a game. I got this game from a bundle so every cent was worth it, I would even consider to buy it with 5 euros if I didn't already have it. But for 10e it's too short.

reviewText: Good ambiance, but there are too many occasions where you can die.\nI understand that it's supposed to scare the player, but having them too many times, with often no idea what you're supposed to do/where you're supposed to go just results in tedious replays of these boring scenes.\nSince you cannot look at your environment and understand what you must do (the killer" moving when you turn your back to it)
date: if you didn't find the clickable spot at first
recommended: you're screwed.\nAnd don't even think of trying to keep "it" in sight while looking at the environment
hoursPlayed: your flashlight often turns off by itself and "it" comes to you to kill you. Again. Not funny.\nAnd to add to that
voteText: there are only savepoints
helpfulPercent: forcing you to redo what you did just because you died earlier just to have another try.\n\nI know some people may not mind
votesHelpful: but I do.\nThis is not what I call a game "fun to play".\nYou can scare me
votesTotal: but you can't force me to do and redo what I did because I didn't click on your secret spot.\n\nInteresting idea
votesFunny: poor execution. You should not give your players Frustration. Ever."

reviewText: I spook really easy where horror games are concerned. This game did not disappoint. It had my heart in my mouth in a few places....... :D The controls are simple, and the graphics are good. The dark bits are really dark, but you have a good-quality flashlight to help with those areas.\n\nThis game is currently listed at £4.79. This isn't too bad a price to pay for this game if you are looking for a bit of a scare. :)

reviewText: I'm not that experienced with horror games, mainly due the fact that most horror games now don't work with the atmosphere, but work a lot with the  jumpscares. But Kraven Manor isn't like this, it gave me an uncanny feeling from the moment that I entered. It was a cool but short experience. I would recommend this game as an intro to more horror games. But watch it's price, Luckly I hooked up with someone to get 2 copies for a decent amount of money, and I must say. Totally worth it!

reviewText:
Really cool atmosphere and concept! The story makes you feel like there is a deep rooted history of Kraven and all the things that has went on in this house. Just walking around you dread the sound of something sneaking up on you which makes the jump scares more intense. I definitely recommend this to anyone that wants to experience a great horror game, play with the lights off!

Kraven Manor Playlist: (Complete)
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLpAx8DRe5ju4uc3zGGgK2CzBGg-c7ZMxk
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Absolutely terrifying! My feelings for this game is that of a love/hate relationship It's so good but so bad all at once! Especially for my heart... There's a few jump scares in there but honestly, the tension is probably the most frightening thing throughout most of the game. Whether you're unaware of what's next or already know what is to come, you still find your adrenaline pumping hella fast. There are two different endings which is also something I love in my games. If you're into horror with multiple endings and find dolls/mannequins creepy, this is a game definitely worth playing!
